Generate Reverse Calendar Mapping for Days Before a Reference Date

Source: R/generate_reverse_day_calendar.R
generate_reverse_day_calendar.Rd

This function builds a calendar that maps days counted backward from a given reference date (e.g., November 1st = DOY 305) to their corresponding calendar dates, months, years, and day-of-year (DOY).

generate_reverse_day_calendar(
  refday = 274,
  lastdays = 1095,
  yearback = 3,
  start_year = 1946
)

Arguments

refday

Integer. The reference day of year (DOY) to count backwards from. For example, November 1st is 305. Default is 274.

lastdays

Integer. Number of days to count backward from the reference date. Default is 1095 (approximately 3 years).

yearback

Integer. Number of full years of historical data needed to cover lastdays. Must be ≥2 if lastdays > 365 or ≥3 if lastdays > 730. Default is 3.

start_year

Integer. The base year from which the calendar sequence begins. Default is 1946. This is useful only for display or internal indexing.

Value

A data frame with the following columns:

DATE

The actual calendar date.

YEAR

The year of the date. Reset to most recent year used for plotting convenience.

MONTHab

Abbreviated month name (e.g., "Jan", "Feb").

DOY

Day of the year (1–366).

days.reversed

The number of days prior to the reference day (1 = the day before refday).

Details

For instance, a days.reversed value of 10 indicates the date 10 days before the specified refday.

The function internally creates a synthetic date range starting from start_year and spanning multiple years (1946 to 1953 by default) to simulate a "calendar of the past." It then identifies reference days in that sequence and maps the days preceding each reference day for a given number of years (yearback). The result is a tidy data frame that shows the relationship between reverse days and actual calendar dates.

Input consistency is checked, and an error is returned if lastdays is too long for the specified yearback.

Examples

# Generate 600 days of lagged calendar data prior to November 1st
calendar_data <- generate_reverse_day_calendar(refday = 305, lastdays = 600, yearback = 3)
#>

head(calendar_data)
#>         DATE YEAR MONTHab DOY referenceFin days.reversed
#> 1 1948-10-31 1948     Oct 305            1             1
#> 2 1948-10-30 1948     Oct 304            0             2
#> 3 1948-10-29 1948     Oct 303            0             3
#> 4 1948-10-28 1948     Oct 302            0             4
#> 5 1948-10-27 1948     Oct 301            0             5
#> 6 1948-10-26 1948     Oct 300            0             6
